title: Biking on the fly
text:
NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: PONGPET MEKLOY - + A reason single tracks are fun to ride is that they're not always the same. Mountain bikers, especially downhillers, are well aware that the character of each trail changes at different times of year. In the dry months, for example, you may have fallen leaves obscuring ruts or rocks along the way, while on any day in the monsoon season you may have fallen branches or even an entire tree blocking your path. 
But the challenging changes brought about by the elements are no match to those created by humans. 
The popular DH trail of Chet Khot-Pong Kon Sao Nature Study and Eco-tourism Centre in Kaeng Khoi, Saraburi, is a case in point. Like bike models, it has been modified and improved many times (by different teams of trail builders) over the past years. Let's check out the latest version. 
Credit to the new development at Chet Khot should be given to the Sathun Team, a nightlife-loving faction of the legendary Park53 group of downhillers and dirt jumpers. Sure enough, these folks did what they are good at, building jumps. 
With members as well as other fellow riders chipping in to buy tools and dirt, the team not only repaired and rebuilt existing jumps, they also added a relatively big, and controversial, tabletop. 
Although it's a mild jump by Park53's standard, some feared that the new addition would be dangerous for novice downhillers. Strong conflicting opinions were posted on social media. But the Sathun team shrugged it off and continued with their work, knowing that a tabletop is a safe type of jump because any rider who is not confident to "fly" can just either roll over it or take the chicken run. 
Among other new additions to the trail is a moderate gap jump with a wide leeway and a waist-high drop where trees flanking the landing are thickly padded, so much so that they look like punching bags, just in case somebody lost control because of the hard landing. This shows that the trail builders do have riders' safety in mind. 
After getting to try the new version of the trail, I can say that Chet Khot is now more fun. The new playthings, especially the tabletop, are great for riders to hone and improve their techniques. As a matter of fact, the tabletop and advice from the Sathun Team riders who happened to be there the day I visited literally took my jumping skill to another level. I jumped higher and farther and safer. 
Chet Khot will be the venue of round two of Thailand Gravity Series 2015 taking place on Sept 19 and 20. If you plan to join the event, you still have two weeks to come and practise. Use the jumps to help you go faster instead of the other way round. 
W ell, see you here again next Thursday. Until then, if you have questions, news or biking insights you wish to share, please feel free to send an email to pongpetm@bangkokpost.co.th or go to Freewheel Bangkok community page on Facebook. Pongpet Mekloy is the Bangkok Post's travel editor and a mountain bike freak. Chet Khot, Saraburi 
GPS coordinates : 14°29'37.55" N 101°09'41.49" E 
Trail condition : Downhill single track. 
Distance : 1.5km. 
Getting there : The easiest way to reach Chet Khot is via Highway 2 (Mitraphap). Just before Thap Kwang there's a pedestrian bridge. At the base of the bridge, on the other side of the highway, you'll see a side road and a sign indicating the way to the eco-tourism centre. There's no public transport service available in these parts. 
Parking : Plenty. 
Food & drinks : There are two simple restaurants at the foot of the hill. The visitors' centre near the camping area has a canteen. Frozen food (a microwave oven is available), snacks and beverages are also available. 
What your family can enjoy while waiting : Take in the beauty of nature. 
Accommodation : The centre offers bungalows, with and without air-con. However, they are all booked for the next two weekends. Some might be available on weekdays, though. If you are not keen on spending the night at the camping ground, there are a few resorts in Kaeng Khoi and more in Muak Lek.
